motion.translation[0].definitions[0].def: the process of moving or the way that someone or something moves
motion.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The rocking motion of the boat made Sylvia feel sick.
motion.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a single movement of your head or hand, especially one made in order to communicate something
motion.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Doyle glanced back at Bodie, and made a slight motion with his head.
He summoned the waiter with a motion of his hand.
motion.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a proposal that is made formally at a meeting, and then is usually decided on by voting
motion.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The motion was defeated by 201 votes to 159.
I urge you to support this motion.
The motion was seconded (=formally supported) by Mr Levin.
The attorneys filed a motion (=made a proposal in a court) for a temporary restraining order.
I’d like to propose a motion to move the weekly meetings to Thursdays.
We will now vote on the motion that membership charges should rise by 15%.
motion.translation[0].definitions[3].def: solid waste material that comes out when you empty your bowels – used especially by doctors and nurses
motion.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to give someone directions or instructions by moving your hand or head
motion.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The police officer motioned for me to pull over.
He motioned to the barman to refill their glasses.
motion to somebody to do something
I saw her motioning me into the room.
motion.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a suggestion that is made formally at a meeting and then decided on by voting
motion.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: The motion was carried (=accepted) by 15 votes to 10.
I’d like to propose a motion to move the weekly meetings to Thursdays.
